name: Tahir
summary: I've been working very long on Alfresco as a Developer. Started with version 2.2. and am still going hard with the latest version.

The first 3 years with Alfresco I was working for a company, then I started my own firm. After my own firm I realized how important the community is. So then I started contributing as in Jira fixes, blogs and after a while on StackOverflow.

After the first Dashlet competition I started writing addons and pieces of code for Alfresco & the community. Now a days I'm developing a lot of stuff, mainly custom modules and I try to blog once in a while.
contributions: Addons: Alfresco Advanced Folder Search, Alfresco AND Search, YouTube Dashlet, Move2Folder
Blogs: http://www.contezza.nl/blog, http://blog.mitco-solutions.com/
Patches: Mostly found in the JIRA, SSO Kerberos fix, WebDavLock fix, Multitentant fix for using an email as username
StackOverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/users/676675/tahir-malik

name: Aingaran

Today Zaizi is one of the biggest Alfresco partners in the world with the highest number Alfresco certified engineers outside of Alfresco. Alfresco EMEA Partner of the year 2012 & 2013.
contributions: Sponsor and organise Alfresco London Meetup, Alfresco Seville Meetup and Content Management Meetup, Sri Lanka.
Used to be active the Alfresco forums, but not enough time to help out as much when you are working on some of the largest Alfresco implementations.

Every now and then I blog at ecmarchitect.com where you can get tips, tricks, and tutorials for Alfresco.

contributions: Recently I have started a blog called alfrescoBlog.com and my latest feature is email tracking inside alfresco, like yesware or getSignals is.

name: Charles
summary: During my studies (10 years ago), I was an active member of my LUG. My first job was in a company specialized in open sourced solutions. In 2004, I started working in ECM with major products like Documentum and IBM FileNet. In 2006, I started exploring Alfresco as I felt it could be the open sourced ECM solutions I was dreaming of ;-)
contributions: Active participation in French forums
Writing blog posts (http://charles.torda.net) when I have time
Explaining to a local business group (Nantes area, France) what is Alfresco and what we can do with it
Contributing to Alfresco Jira (https://issues.alfresco.com/jira/browse/MNT-9755, https://issues.alfresco.com/jira/browse/ACE-1405)
I also produced two Alfresco extensions (Image Finder, My Network dashlets)... but they need to be updated

name: Andreas

Helping people on StackOverflow

name: Marcus
summary: I'm an Alfresco consultant working for the Alfresco partner Redpill Linpro in Sweden. I have been working with alfresco for a few years and I've always had much help from community at the forums and blog posts etc.
contributions: I'm trying to answer questions on the forum when they are within my area of expertise.

Since 2013 I've been in charge of the open source project which supplies a simple way to integrate online editing with LibreOffice from Alfresco Share http://addons.alfresco.com/addons/libreoffice-online-edit-module
Since this year I'm also involved in the translation project at Crowdin where I together with other people translate Alfresco + RM into Swedish.

When working with new clients in my work I always try to find parts of the work that could be useful for other people. I have created some repos on github where such content has been published. So far most of it is without documentation, but that will follow when time allows.

name: Ben
contributions: active role in the Alfresco forums
reported bugs in Alfresco Community to Alfresco

name: Ashley
summary: I've been involved on-and-off with Alfresco development for a number of years in my current role at Surevine. Over those years I have been heavily involved in the development and deployment of a number of extensions for Alfresco.
contributions: Some of developed extensions are open source and some currently in the process of being open sourced (see https://github.com/surevine/?query=alfresco )
I presented at Alfresco DevCon (when they were still called that) a few years back and earned myself a t-shirt! :)

name: Bindu
summary: I am the chief architect at Zia Consulting, which is a Platinum Parter of Alfresco. We have been partner of the year a couple of times. As a platinum partner we can't work on community projects through work. However, there is nothing stopping folks working on community related projects in our spare time :)
contributions: I enjoy hanging out on IRC and answering questions if I can. I presented a dev environment we built during TTL #69 that I hope inspired the new RAD stuff in the 2.0 SDK at least a little bit.

I have also presented some lightning talks at DevCon/Summit and will be presenting a full session at Summit in SF and London this year that I hope will be interesting to (and advocating for) the community.

name: Gloria
summary: I am the Localisation Manager at Alfresco, managing the terminology and localisation of Alfresco products into the core official languages (French, German, Italian, Spanish, Japanese, Dutch, Russian, Norwegian, Brazilian Portuguese and Simplified Chinese). The term lists and translation memories are available for members of the community upon request.

name: David
summary: I've been working on Share and the APIs it uses for 4.5 years, after joining Alfresco's engineering team. I've touched most areas of Share, its APIs, but calendar, date/time and localisation and hybrid sync issues keep finding their way to my desk. I come from a web development background, so love the fact that client side technologies just won't stand still.

Recently I've been working on moving existing Share functionality to Aikau, the 5.0 search improvements as well as background tasks like development environment improvements, bringing in Grunt, simplifying maven usage and the way we run UI unit tests.
contributions: I blog at http://blogs.alfresco.com/wp/dwebster/
I have code at https://github.com/davidcognite
I try and make code to the Summits, where I usually present a session or two on new Share developments and enjoy the hack-a-thons.
